debateinfo.title: FINANCIAL SECTOR REFORM (AMENDMENTS AND TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL (No. 1) 1999

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Hockey, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

I rise today to introduce three bills that represent the culmination of the government's financial system reform efforts over the last few years. The reforms spelt out in these bills were initiated in response to the report of the financial system inquiry, chaired by Stan Wallis. They represent a further step along path of financial system regulatory enhancements.

Such regulation should not stand in the way of economic and technological progress; nor should it promote the interests of one group over another. Instead, financial system regulation should provide a sound, stable and predictable environment to encourage the creation of wealth, and to facilitate trade.

As we approach the end of this millennium, it is helpful to consider these changes in the wider perspective of both international financial system developments and changes to the Australian regulatory environment.

And there have been massive changes. Twenty years ago, if you wanted to access your money, you had to go to your local branch between 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., Monday to Friday. Back then, the automatic teller machine was just a distant idea, credit cards were virtually unknown, and no-one could spell `EFTPOS', let alone pronounce it.

Now, two decades later, and as my colleague the Treasurer has stated, we have the lowest interest rates since man last walked on the moon. At least today you can borrow relatively easily, including over the phone and Internet. Back when Jack Schmitt ascended to the Apollo 17 lunar module on 14 December 1972—the last man on the moon—interest rates were at a similar level. But it was virtually impossible for the majority of people to borrow money. Going cap in hand to your local branch manager, you were lucky to get a small proportion of a housing loan at the reasonable interest rate. The balance of a housing loan was made up from an assortment of sources at considerably higher rates of interest, often up to five percentage points more.

In 1981 the then Treasurer, now our Prime Minister, received a report on the performance of financial regulation completed by the Australian financial inquiry. This formed the basis of many of the regulatory changes of the 1980s, including the floating of the Australian dollar.
In the years following that report, it became clear to many that further reform was not just desirable but essential.
Honourable members will be aware that the Treasurer introduced into the House last year a package of legislation to complete the first stage of the government's financial sector reform program.

That package of legislation instituted wide-ranging measures aimed at improving the efficiency, competitiveness and stability of Australia's financial system. Included among those measures were the creation of a single prudential regulator, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA), the strengthening of Australia's payments system with the creation of a Payments System Board within the Reserve Bank, and a refocusing of disclosure and consumer protection through the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC).

The purpose of this bill is to provide for the transfer of regulatory responsibility from the states and territories of Australia to the Commonwealth of building societies, credit unions and friendly societies. This bill will allow building societies and credit unions to better compete with banks and to operate outside their existing state and territory boundaries.

As such, consumers will have a greater selection of financial service providers and a greater selection of financial products. In other words, Australian consumers will have greater choice. Providing consumers with greater choice is a further example of this government's commitment to consumer empowerment and its commitment to consumer sovereignty.

The bill will also provide a single regulatory framework for life insurance companies and friendly societies, while recognising the special features of friendly societies. The amendments also strengthen regulation for life insurance and increase the flexibility of its application.

All told, about 20 building societies, 237 credit unions and 85 friendly societies will be involved in the regulatory transfer. These organisations represent 1,326 branches nationally, with $38 billion in assets and 12,420 employees.

To complement this package, state and territory governments will be signing with the Commonwealth a financial sector regulation transfer agreement and enacting legislation within their jurisdictions to effect this regulatory transfer.
Then, for the first time in the history of the Commonwealth, there will be a single, consistent, regulatory regime for deposit taking institutions, life and general insurance, and superannuation.
The bill also proposes to make sundry minor amendments to correct errors that have been detected in the relevant acts and to improve consistency.

This bill highlights that, as Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, I am more than just the `minister for banking'. I am also the minister for building societies, credit unions, friendly societies, insurance companies, asset managers, custodians, trustees, financial advisers and superannuation funds, to name just a few.

It is also an opportunity for me to represent one of the country's fastest growing sectors—a sector employing hundreds of thousands of Australians, a sector that is strongly contributing to our record economic growth, and a sector which is innovative and integral to our continued effort to secure Australia's place as a centre for global financial services.
I will now turn to the bill in more detail.
Amendment of the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority Act 1998 (APRA Act)

The bill will expand and clarify APRA's ability to take on functions as a result of an agreement with a state or territory. This will enable APRA to be contracted to provide prudential regulation and advisory services on a fee for service basis subject to the agreement of the minister. The Commonwealth, states and territories agreed that state and territory governments would remain responsible for the prudential regulation of housing cooperatives and trustee companies but they will be able to enter into an agreement with APRA to provide prudential regulation or advice services for those entities.
Amendment of the Banking Act 1959 (Banking Act) and the Reserve Bank Act 1959 (Reserve Bank Act)

The bill proposes to apply the Criminal Code—which is scheduled to come into force by March 2000—to the Banking Act and the Reserve Bank Act. There will be no change in the penalties associated with any of the offences.

To ensure consistency between banks and other deposit-taking institutions, the bill proposes to extend the banking holiday and unclaimed moneys provisions to all authorised deposit-taking institutions.
The bill also proposes to extend the scope of APRA's standards and directions powers and to facilitate the development of voluntary industry support arrangements.
Amendment of the Corporations Law

To enable the transfer of regulatory responsibility of building societies, credit unions and friendly societies to the Commonwealth, a new schedule will be added to the Corporations Law that will provide for the registration of financial institutions and friendly societies as companies and the regulation of those companies under the Corporations Law by ASIC.

Both the Ministerial Council for Corporations (MINCO) and the Ministerial Council for Financial Institutions (MINFIN) have unanimously approved the proposed amendments to the Corporations Law in the bill. Unanimous agreement of MINCO and MINFIN ministers is required under the Corporations Agreement, because the amendments will have the effect of extending coverage of the Corporations Law to various classes of financial institutions established under state and territory statutes.
The objective of the new schedule is to facilitate the registration of the entities as companies with as little disturbance to operations, and as little conversion costs, as possible.

In line with this objective, the bill is structured so that at the transfer date, the entities themselves need do little to give effect to the transfer. Entities will be deemed to be registered as a company type that most closely fits their current structure, unless they elect to be registered as a different category prior to transfer. The bill provides for a transitional period of 18 months following the transfer day. Entities will be given this period to make the necessary changes to their own rules to recognise their new status as a company.

The change to a company form is not expected to present significant difficulties for the institutions concerned, since much of the Corporations Law regulatory framework already applies to them through the respective governing codes. However, there are some matters that will require exemptions and modifications to be made. Most of these are of a transitional nature, such as the publication of Australian company numbers on documents, but there are some matters that are likely to justify ongoing relief from ordinary Corporations Law provisions. There are facilities in the bill to make regulations with respect to such matters. Furthermore, there are powers on the part of ASIC to make exemption and modification orders to facilitate the transition.

The existing conduct and disclosure obligations which apply to friendly society benefit fund products will, as far as possible, be maintained pending the current review of conduct and disclosure obligations applying to financial products under the Government's Corporate Law Economic Reform Program.
Amendment of the Life Insurance Act 1995 (the Life Act)

The transfer of friendly societies to the Commonwealth regime will increase contestability in the market for life insurance products. Until recently, multiple prudential regimes applied to life insurance business offered by financial institutions in different jurisdictions. In late 1997, a unified state scheme was created for state based friendly societies under the guardianship of the Australian Financial Institutions Commission (AFIC). As friendly societies are still in transition under those arrangements, it is appropriate to make their entry into the life insurance regime as seamless as possible in the first instance.

To achieve this, it is proposed that for a transition period, the detailed requirements in respect of friendly societies—particularly in regard to actuarial standards—will be reinstated on the basis existing under the AFIC regime. However, this should not be taken to imply that friendly societies are subject to lower prudential standards during this transition period. The development of the AFIC standards was based significantly on the existing, relevant actuarial standards set by the Life Insurance Actuarial Standards Board under the Life Act. Differences between the two sets of standards are intended to reflect the structural and operational differences in the respective industries.

In the longer term, it is proposed to harmonise the actuarial standards for all companies registered under the Life Insurance Act to the extent appropriate given these structural differences between friendly societies and other life companies.

The arrangements will retain the distinct identity of friendly societies so that the industry differentiation can continue. This enhances choice to consumers. For example, the unique benefit fund structure and rules of friendly societies are to be recognised in legislation.

Other changes open up opportunities for the development of new prudentially regulated products under the life insurance regime. In particular, companies will be able to have certain insurance, annuity or financial benefit business declared to be life insurance business so that it can be offered in a prudentially regulated environment alongside other life insurance business.

Consistent with the thrust of the first stage of the financial sector reform, APRA's powers will be enhanced to facilitate early intervention in the life insurance market. Prudential requirements will be able to be set to better match the profile of the life insurer.
Miscellaneous amendments
The bill proposes a number of minor miscellaneous amendments to several acts, correcting previous drafting errors and improving clarity within those acts. In addition:

. states and territories will be able to confer powers and functions on ASIC which, prior to the regulatory transfer, were performed by state and territories in relation to transferring financial institutions.
. Friendly societies that operate both life insurance business and health insurance business will be able to be jointly regulated under the two regimes.
Consequential amendments
The bill proposes a number of consequential amendments to various acts to amend references to `friendly societies', `credit unions' and `building societies' where necessary and appropriate.
The bill also provides transferring institutions 18 months in which to obtain necessary approvals under the Financial Sector (Shareholdings) Act 1998.
Amendments to the taxation laws will ensure appropriate taxation treatment of transferring friendly societies, including for RSA business.
Transitional, Saving and Application Provisions

To ensure the smooth transfer of institutions to the Commonwealth, the bill proposes a number of transitional, saving and application provisions. These provisions include the transfer of staff to APRA, the transfer of assets and liabilities from state and territory regulatory bodies to APRA and ASIC as appropriate, the granting of authorities and approvals for the use of business names, and transitional provisions relating to unclaimed moneys.

The provisions include a number of transitional regulation-making powers which are intended to be of limited duration and which need to be developed in consultation with the states and territories and industry.
I commend this historic bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Ms Macklin) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Hockey, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

In transferring responsibility from the states and territories to the Commonwealth, the Commonwealth was aware that there were some parts of state and territory laws which were not allowed for under the Commonwealth regime.

The state and territory regulated entities such as building societies, credit unions and friendly societies along with the Commonwealth, were keen to ensure that these groups were not disadvantaged by the transfer. In fact, the Commonwealth's view was that some of these provisions were very useful prudential regulation tools.

Transfers of business was one such power. Under the state and territory legislation, building societies, credit unions and friendly societies were able to transfer their business amongst themselves with the approval of the regulator. The Commonwealth is keen to provide a similar mechanism as it will provide an efficient and effective prudential tool for protecting depositors or policy owner moneys where their institution is in severe financial hardship. It is also good to facilitate change in the industry.

This bill contains that proposed mechanism. As a result, the Commonwealth has carried over this useful prudential tool and extended it to all authorised deposit taking institutions and also all life insurance companies.

There are two types of transfer of business. The first is voluntary where two entities apply to the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority to transfer part or all of one entity's business to the other. If APRA is satisfied that the transfer is in the interests of depositors or policy owners, and other criteria are satisfied, then with the approval of the minister, APRA may approve the transfer.

The second type of transfer of business is a compulsory transfer. These can only be done in limited circumstances, where the transfer is in the interests of policy owners or depositors. It is expected that in circumstances such as severe financial hardship, where an entity was no longer able to meet it's financial requirements, APRA may seek the agreement of a receiving body to accept the business of the transferring body, and thus protect the interests of depositors or policy owners.
This is a proven effective and useful prudential tool that will complement APRA's other powers under the Banking Act 1959 and the Life Insurance Act 1995.
I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Ms Macklin) adjourned.

debateinfo.title: INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT (RSAS PROVIDED BY REGISTERED ORGANIZATIONS) BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Hockey, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

The accompanying bill dealing with the transfer of financial institutions from the state to the Commonwealth regulatory regime provides for friendly societies that operate benefit fund business to become regulated as life insurance companies. By becoming life companies under Commonwealth legislation, friendly societies will be able to seek approval to be a retirement savings account (RSA) institution so as to provide RSA business.

Therefore, the transfer of friendly societies into the Commonwealth regime opens up opportunities for the industry to conduct new business. This outcome will be achieved by having friendly societies enter a competitively neutral financial market. New entry into the RSA market increases competition for retirement savings products and expands the choice available to consumers.
This also means that another Wallis report recommendation will be met—recommendation 43 that sought the extension of the right to offer RSAs to other APRA regulated institutions.

A necessary consequence of this extension of RSA business is to provide appropriate tax treatment for RSA business of friendly societies and other registered organisations. The accompanying bill includes amendments to the taxation legislation to achieve this. This bill amends the Income Tax Rates Act 1986 to specify the rates of tax that apply to the RSA business of friendly societies and other registered organisations. The RSA business of friendly societies and other registered organisations will be taxed at the same rate that applies to the RSA business of competing entities, including life insurance companies and banks.

In particular, income credited by a friendly society to an RSA will be taxed at the 15 per cent rate applying to complying superannuation savings. Any profit generated by the friendly society will be taxed at the company tax rate.
I commend this historic bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.

debate.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I would like to tell the House of the experiences of a growing number of people in the Fowler electorate whose overseas relatives have been denied visitor visas to Australia. The policy of rejecting visitor visas on the basis of the nationality of the applicant is felt most severely in the Fowler electorate. With the highest proportion of residents born outside Australia, it is not surprising that many families in Fowler are feeling the effects of having close relatives denied visitor visas.

speech.para: In addition, Fowler has a high concentration of people from Asia, the Middle East and the former Yugoslavia. Many are from areas which are not obviously on the list of countries for which stringent conditions apply. The tighter application of this policy has caused considerable uncertainty, anxiety and distress among many of my constituents. For many people who have contributed greatly to our community, and our nation, the denial of the request of a loved one to visit them in Australia is an affront and a reflection on their Australian citizenship. They feel as if they are being treated as second-class citizens because of the country of origin.

Let me mention just a few of the many cases brought to me to illustrate the impact of these policies. In the first case, an elderly man suffering from a terminal illness, and in hospital, requested his daughter, resident overseas, to visit him urgently. The visitor visa application was denied causing great distress to the dying man as well as to his family here in Australia. The application was approved on appeal, by which time the father's health had declined to the extent that the visit was of doubtful benefit.

Family ties are a feature of most cultures. Where Australian families have ageing parents overseas, it is understandable that they wish to receive visits from them. It can be less costly and require less time away from the workplace and school where parents visit Australia rather than have the whole family travelling overseas. They will probably choose Qantas and bring some foreign exchange with them.

In another case, the parents of a local family were denied a visa on health grounds, despite the family arranging health insurance for their parents. They had made provision for any unfortunate event which might happen to them. I point out to the House that these parents have visited Australia previously. I had one very sad case where a mother was refused a visa for a Christmas visit, despite having entered and departed Australia within the specified time on three previous occasions. The mother, widowed on Christmas Day 1995, had adopted a pattern of spending Christmas with her daughter in Australia. Unfortunately, this widowed lady did not spend Christmas 1998 with her beloved family in Australia.

I am not in the business of criticising the decision makers, the senior migration officers at the Australian overseas post. I believe they have an awful job, despite the attractions of fulfilling a role in an Australian embassy. But it has become more prudent for their answer to be no. That carries with it the burden of a possible appeal. The field is narrowed, though, because an appeal can only be lodged by a close family member—not a cousin or a close friend or anyone else, and certainly not the applicant.

The cultural suspicion in which migration officers work has risen in my experience over many years of dealing with such cases. Those families in my electorate who had no problems in the past in having loved ones visit them at special times or otherwise are now feeling that suspicion. They are feeling that they are unreliable, deceitful or plain dishonest. In many cases they are experiencing those uncomfortable feelings that made living unbearable in their countries of origin. This should not be happening to Australian families.

In many instances where visitor applications are rejected, the applicants plainly have no intention of overstaying. Applicants with dependent families in their home countries are assumed to present a risk on the basis of their nationality alone. No account seems to be taken of their personal circumstances.

With the Olympics to be held in Australia next year, many Australian families will no doubt offer their relatives overseas the opportunity to visit and attend Olympic events. This opportunity should be open to all Australians, regardless of their country of origin.

talk.start.para: —In September 1950 Sir Robert Menzies, the then Prime Minister of Australia, released details of a national service training scheme for compulsory military service within the Navy, Army and Air Force for all men aged 18 years. The scheme lasted until 1959. In the Army the scheme was structured for three call-ups per year. Military training for 98 days duration was followed by three years—later two years—of compulsory training in the Citizens Military Forces. The initial training period for the Navy and the Air Force was six months, followed by five years of general service.

speech.para: Each state had its own special training unit. In Queensland it was Wacol; in Victoria it was Puckapunyal for the Army Nashos, it was Amberley and Point Cook for the Air Force, and it was HMAS Penguin for the Navy conscripts. It has been estimated that, during 1951 to 1959, up to 250,000 Nashos served their country across the three services. In Queensland approximately 40,000 Nashos passed through Wacol. Faced with the Cold War and the `domino theory', teenagers from all walks of life were called up: canecutters, university students, tradesmen and some fresh out of school. It was a time when many left home as boys and returned as men. Now known as Australia's forgotten forces, they were conscripted and trained to defend our northern shores against the `yellow peril'. Fortunately, this invasion never came.

In the period 1965 to 1972, military conscription was reintroduced with the Vietnam conflict. A total of 761,854 men who turned 20 between 1965 and 1972 were potentially eligible for call-up into the Army. The scheme also differed by being a lottery rather than a universal for all age eligible males. Around 64,000 men served their time, which was two years, following on from the first intake on 30 June 1965. Various training centres were used. No recruit training battalions were in Queensland. Of these men, 23,000 served in Vietnam, making up 50 per cent of the Australian task force; 187 were killed in action and 1,479 were wounded. On 7 December 1972, national service was discontinued.

The National Servicemen's Association was established by the late Barry Vicary in 1987 and was first based in Toowoomba, Queensland. In 1994 the organisation was incorporated under Queensland's Incorporation Act under the name National Servicemen's Association of Australia (Queensland) Inc. The association has a growing membership across all parts of Queensland and interstate. It also has links with the NSAA branches interstate for the national advancement of welfare of Nashos and their dependants. Other broad aims of the National Servicemen's Association include promoting the good name and community knowledge of the association and its aims.

The membership focus is primarily on Australian Nashos in the period 1951 to 1972, but membership of the association is open to persons and organisations of good repute who support the association's aims and constitution. Members receive a regular newsletter, Nashos News, and access to association events and services, memorabilia and merchandise. Reciprocal arrangements with kindred associations also exist.

The members of the Caboolture National Servicemen's Association, led by Eric Beutel, are concerned that, with Wacol now looking like it is going to pass out of Defence hands, the chapel that so many of them went to for prayer and for solace during their time in the defence forces will also go with it. I have made representations on their behalf to the Minister for Defence and I am sure this government will be mindful of the concerns of this group. They are a fine body of men who are now banding together to support each other and to offer ongoing connections which have been lost over many years.

The interesting part is that, when I attended one of their functions not so long ago, all but one actually felt that it was necessary for us to continue with national service today. I wonder how these men would feel today when they see the actions of young people who, inspired by what I do not know, engage in vandalism in a political party's headquarters for no reason other than to be political opportunists acting in a disgraceful manner. It is probably for that reason that they feel things such as that the discipline imposed by the National Servicemen's Association would go a long way to addressing those problems.

I feel sorry today that people have taken industrial action in such a manner, vandalising a political party's headquarters that has not the most remote or direct connection with the concerns that they hold. It is a sad day for Australia and I hope it is one that is not repeated in the future. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Tonight I want to continue some of the remarks I made on Monday, International Women's Day, about women. I applauded some of the women who have given so much to the cause of equality. Some of those women were members of the Union of Australian Women, which was formed in 1950. Australians, and in particular Australian women, have every right to be proud of the fact that Australia was one of the first countries to grant women the right to vote, beginning with South Australia in 1902. However, Australian women today despair at the Howard government's policies that have hurt them over the past three years.

speech.para: Before I detail just how unfair this government is to Australian women, I want to highlight some historic milestones for women since 1988. In 1988 the Labor government released the first national agenda for women. In 1989 Rosemary Follett was elected ACT Chief Minister, becoming the first female head of government. 1990 saw the election of two women state Premiers, Carmen Lawrence and Joan Kirner, and Lowitja O'Donoghue was appointed the first chair of ATSIC. 1991 saw the first female state Governor appointed. Another historic event occurred in 1995, when Jennie George became the first female president of the ACTU. 1996 was a great year for women, particularly Aboriginal women, when Nova Peris-Kneebone became Australia's first Aboriginal to win a gold medal as a member of the Australian women's hockey team. Margaret Reid became the first female President of the Senate. In 1997 Regina Graycar was appointed Australia's first professor of women and law at the University of Sydney and Judy Raper became the only current woman dean of an engineering faculty in Australia, again at the University of Sydney. In 1998 two women, Cathy Freeman and Tan Le, were named Australian and Young Australian of the Year.

Of course, much has improved for women since the early days but the need for further reforms is undeniable. We still have a long way to go to achieve equality for women, not only in Australia but throughout the world. Women still remain underrepresented in decision making positions at all levels in our society. Under this government's policies, women are being systematically stripped of their hard-won gains. Savage cuts to child care have made it increasingly difficult for women to stay in the work force. There has been no progress made on the gender earnings gap, with women still earning only 83 per cent of men's wages. No progress has been made in women's participation in the labour market, with the proportion of women participating in the work force remaining stuck at about 53.7 per cent. Latest figures show that 13,000 women left the labour force in January 1999 alone. Compare this with the achievements of the Labor government in the 1980s, when the proportion of women participating in the work force rose by 7 per cent.

The Howard government does not stop here. The GST will be an added burden for women as they fight to meet increased costs within the household budget. Over-the-counter medicines and health products such as cough mixtures, baby needs, pain relievers and sanitary items will all have a 10 per cent tax—these items are currently tax free. Child-care costs will go up even further under the GST, making it even more difficult for women to be able to afford to go to work. Minister Reith's plan to cut wages and social security for people on low incomes targets women because it is, once again, women who are concentrated in the lowest income groups and women who are in the majority when it comes to social security recipients.

The Prime Minister should be made aware that his policies towards women are being watched by the world. The United Nations Committee on Eliminating Discrimination Against Women came to the conclusion that this government's policies had slowed down or reversed Australia's progress in achieving equality in areas of housing, child care and employment programs. They also expressed a real concern that programs that were of benefit to women, such as heath and access to legal aid, could be subject to further budget cuts. This government should also remember that one of the things they cannot take away from women is the vote.

talk.start.para: —I would like to thank my National Party colleagues and some Liberals who have fought very hard on the issue of the petrol bill which other people voted on earlier today. On this issue we have secured an undertaking that there will be no repeal of the sites act until the oil industry code is agreed to. I would like to single out John Forrest, who has shown in another place exceptional intellectual courage and integrity, and also De-Anne Kelly, without whose intellectual abilities and very public stand on this issue before the last election the service station owner-operators would not now be in the strong position they are in. Finally, the Motor Trades Association of Australia have fought intelligently and responsibly this difficult battle, and I have every confidence they will win.

speech.para: I abstained from voting, from crossing the floor, on the basis that this legislation will not be promulgated until the Motor Trades Association, the service station operators, agree to the petroleum industry code. If these protections are removed, we will not have 9,000 people selling fuel in Australia; we will have six people selling fuel in Australia.
Mrs Irwin interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The honourable member's government removed the 6c we had in country areas to help us compete with the city areas, which have much cheaper petrol. They also raised the taxation from 22.7c a litre to 37.3c a litre, which is 21c a litre imposed upon country people by the ALP. It would be an act of arch hypocrisy for them to come into this place and then talk about it.
—Why didn't you vote?

—I have secured an agreement, which is more than you have secured. During the term of the ALP government in this place, all the efforts to restrain the oil companies which were undertaken by the Menzies-McEwen government when they introduced a price at the wellhead and all the actions undertaken by the Fraser-Anthony government were completely undermined by Mr Keating and his economic rationalist policies, which enabled the oil companies to take the price of petrol from 12.6c a litre to the oil companies when the ALP took office to 25c a litre to the oil companies. That is what they did under you people. In the same period of time the price of a barrel of oil dropped clean in half worldwide. Unless we restrain the oil companies, they will go in and compete against the small service stations and simply wipe them out.
—You should have been in here voting.

—I officially abstained, which is more than any person on that side of the House has done. The reason why under the ALP government the oil companies were able to take an extra 20c a litre in the marketplace that they were not entitled to was that we could not secure from the ALP government, as we are failing to secure from the present government, an agreement that a minimum price be put in. If a minimum price is put into the system then anyone can get petrol in from overseas. As Allan Fels said—it is the only time in my life I have ever agreed with Allan Fels—Woolworths will be of advantage and will do great things in the marketplace with respect to petrol. What he meant was that he, like me, is well aware of the fact that you cannot raise off anyone the $23 million to compete with the oil companies. Woolworths think they are big enough and strong enough to be able to do this, and good luck to them. But, if a minimum price was put in, let me say to you, Mr Speaker, that anybody could get petrol in from overseas because the petrol is so damn cheap overseas.

speech.para: A good friend of mine, Mr Neil Turner, a former Speaker of the parliament in Queensland, attempted to bring petrol in from Venezuela. The Venezuelans said they would put up the $23 million, except that every time they had done this before the oil companies indulged in predatory pricing, dropped the price on them, and they lost a lot of money. They were not prepared to do that again. But, if they were given minimum pricing protection, they would be prepared to do that.

The answer is there in neon flashing lights. We wish Woolworths well in their endeavours. This is the only time I have ever spoken well about Woolworths, and it will be the last time, I can assure you. However, we need more than that. We need minimum price protection until we get proper anti-trust legislation such as the Americans have—and the Supreme Court in the United States has utilised that to ban vertical integration. The Supreme Court there stops this sort of thing from happening.

I give great praise to the Fraser-Anthony government for introducing this legislation. I pray that the promises and undertakings that have been given to us are going to be honoured in the same way that the promises given to the motor trades before the last election are going to be honoured. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to speak about the future of community legal centres in Australia. They are under threat from both the federal and state governments, particularly in Victoria. There has recently been a review of Victoria's community legal centres and their funding, commissioned jointly by the federal and state governments. It proposed the establishment of an implementation advisory group to examine access to community legal centres.

speech.para: This was called a review, although it is really a report, a lengthy and detailed document, with some worrying directions mapped out in it. The report talks about improving access to legal services for the disadvantaged, but I fear that any action taken in this direction will actually have the opposite effect. There is uncertainty about the make-up and role of the implementation group and doubt about the government's intention to look critically at whether the recommendations are workable.

The review discussed the possibility of amalgamating the 19 community legal centres in Victoria into just four regional areas, in line with the community and family services departmental areas in Victoria. It looked at the possibility of policy and advocacy matters being dealt with by only one central body. An attack is being made here on three clear levels. There is this first attack on regionalisation. There is a second attack on the access to justice—and, if time allows, I intend to go into some detail about that, using the Footscray Legal Service as an example of the important role that community legal centres play in providing services to our community and access to justice. The third area where the attack is very clear is in the policy and advocacy roles that these community centres play. We must ask why the various governments are so afraid of these community centres having the capacity to speak out on issues of law reform and police and other matters.

Locally, in my electorate, the Federation of Community Legal Services has launched a strong campaign against these changes. In particular, Footscray Legal Service and the Western Suburbs Legal Service in Newport—both in my electorate—have organised meetings to deal with and discuss community response to the proposed changes.

A meeting held on 3 March in Footscray was attended by 150 people. That meeting expressed its unanimous concern about the review process and where that process might lead, particularly in our region. I congratulate the centre in Footscray for its actions and for the care and concern it has shown for our community as a whole and for those who from time to time find themselves in desperate need of the legal advice and assistance that the community centres can provide.

The western suburbs of Melbourne are going to be particularly hard hit by these proposals, if they are implemented. The seven legal centres currently in the area range from Werribee to Flemington through North Melbourne, Essendon and Deer Park. As anyone who is familiar with the geography of North Melbourne will know, this is a very broad region. There is massive diversity. For example, the specialised needs of the community in Footscray, with its very high demand for non-English speaking background skills, are different to the largely Anglo-Saxon community in, for example, Werribee.

The statistics are quite staggering. The Footscray centre services people who have come to Australia from 72 different countries. Twenty-seven per cent of those are Vietnamese born; 22 per cent of the clientele of the Footscray legal service arrived in Australia only in the 1990s. This proposal may see the Footscray Legal Service moved to Werribee. As well as being a very different community, Werribee is a 45-minute drive away from Footscray Legal Service's current base. The majority of the clients of these legal centres are on government benefits—up to 62 per cent, with seven per cent or eight per cent having no income whatsoever. It is, therefore, clear that many will be relying on public transport. That means they would have to travel at least an hour by train, including one change of train, to attend the centre if it moved to Werribee.

As well, a huge number of volunteers—approximately 700 in Victoria—work in the community legal centres. They volunteer for these community services because they want to participate in their local community and not in some distant area.

We are concerned about access to justice. The proposal also deals with excluding people who do not have a health care card from the services of a legal service. This would mean, for example, that a migrant woman who was unfairly dismissed from her job but whose husband works only part time would not be entitled to this free legal advice. A young person who may be harassed by the police but has a single parent who works will also have nowhere to go.

I am concerned that the real agenda of the government is to silence the community legal centres because of the very effective role they have played in advocacy and in pursuing policy and law reform. This argument is over what is a tiny budget of $5 million, shared between the state and Commonwealth governments. That budget services a huge number of people. In my state of Victoria, 50,000 people have used the services of the legal centres, with another 70,000 client contacts who have
not needed ongoing legal advice in that state. I urge the government not to go down this path and to recognise the vital role that the community services play in our community. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In Townsville we are currently building the Sun Metals Zinc Refinery, which is the largest Korean investment in the world outside Korea. Unfortunately, 10 days ago construction at the site was brought to a halt because of an inter-union dispute. Two unions came up from the south, and all the men have been pulled out. About 1,000 men are currently outside the gates of the refinery.

speech.para: As the days have gone by, I have been very disturbed to see the behaviour of these men. We have had sexual and racial slurs thrown at the people going through the gates of the refinery. We do not need terms such as `dog eaters' and `slit eye' expletives sent to our Korean friends. It sends the wrong message to people who are prepared to invest in Australia. It is a shame that, on the day that we have seen an increase of 32,900 in employment in February, we have this going on in Townsville. I urge the men to get back to work and to get this site working again.

business.start.para: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER(Mr Nehl) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: —I thank the Queensland state member for Clayfield, Mr Santo Santoro, for his most generous offer to refer to me again in the state parliament as repayment for any comments I care to make about him. I am thankful for his efforts and the further opportunity to highlight to the parliament the atrocious behaviour of the Liberal Party at the 1998 Queensland state election. Mr Santoro is quick to comment on others, but few carry the sort of political baggage that comes when you make a career of grubby political deals.

speech.para: No matter how hard Mr Santoro tries to hide from his decision, no-one will forget the results of the short-sighted and nasty agenda that brought shame to the state of Queensland, the Queensland Liberal Party, and Mr Santoro's own cultural heritage. Make no mistake, Mr Santo Santoro is more responsible than any other person for the 11 seats won by One Nation. It was his preference deal, his and a couple of his Canberra mates.

Mr Santoro attacks me for my lack of achievement. He, on the other hand, is a major player in Queensland politics and, after all, only Santo can claim direct credit for the election of so many Queensland MPs. He can claim the credit for the One Nation Party wins of Jeff Knuth in Burdekin, Bill Feldman in Caboolture, Ken Turner in Thuringowa, Harry Black in Whitsunday, David Dalgliesh of Hervey Bay and John Kingston in Maryborough. And how can we forget Santo's inspired support of Mr Jack Paff in Ipswich West and the short political career of Charles Rappolt in Mulgrave? How proud Mr Santo Santoro must be of his fine recruits with so many of them being men. Without the help of Mr Santoro, the One Nation Party would have won only three seats in Queensland. Given the current state of One Nation drop-off, none of them would be left today.

Mr Santo Santoro's flirtation with Pauline Hanson and One Nation will not be quickly forgotten by the people of Queensland. Apart from promoting destructive political forces into prominence, what has Mr Santoro really achieved? Everyone is well aware of his federal ambitions, yet he still languishes in a position he believes he has long outgrown. He remains a small fish in his own small pond. Having personally reduced the Queensland Liberal Party to only nine seats, Santo only needs about five friends and the would-be could be leader. However, his federal ambitions have not abated. He is looking around on, I think, Brisbane's north side right now and eyeing off a few potential federal seats.

Mr Santo Santoro is out of touch. He scoffs as he describes my service in the RAAF as do-nothing. This view is not shared, I am sure, by thousands of Australians who have either served, or are currently serving, in the Australian defence forces. Perhaps if Mr Santo Santoro spent more time in Queensland listening to his constituents and less time in Canberra dreaming of a future missed, he would be better placed to comment.

Mr Santo Santoro derides the achievement of Labor in assuring female representation in parliament. Yet the failings of the Queensland Libs is elementary according to Dr Watson, Leader of the Queensland Liberals, who said:
The great wins of Cameron Thompson, Mal Brough, Ian Macfarlane, Warren Entsch and Peter Lindsay prove that a Liberal can gain support in a wide variety of areas.
Mr Santo Santoro, where are the women?
But still the issues remain. Mr Santoro and the Liberal executive made the decision to not put One Nation last. As Dr Watson also said:
When they believe you are not holding firm to your principles, they will punish you and punish you they rightfully did.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In contrast to the Labor Party who spent their time attacking an individual, this side of the House wants to praise an individual, namely, Mrs Evelyn Thompson who was named as the Sutherland Shire Citizen of the Year for 1999.

speech.para: If ever there was a person who well deserved the title, `salt of the earth', it is Evelyn Thompson, mother of two children, grandmother of two. She has been a resident of Sutherland Shire for 48 years. She established the Caring Centre in the shire some 25 years ago, has continued in her involvement since that time, and is the president. The centres have been established for the aged and their carers and there are 24 centres throughout Sutherland Shire.

She also established and is now president of the Twilight Committee, the charity that raises funds for the rehabilitation unit for Sutherland Hospital. She has been involved for 29 years in the Twilight Committee group. They were involved in refurbishment of a ward and built a hydrotherapy pool at Sutherland Hospital.

She is also the founding chairman of the Sutherland Shire Family Network and now works as a volunteer for that particular group, the Hope for the Children charity. She has been involved with that for six years. She was the president of the ladies auxiliary of Port Hacking High School and secretary of the P&C at the school. She was involved on the canteen committee and was the chairman of the Air League.

Mrs Thompson is also a long-term member of the Liberal Party in our area. But it is her involvement in the community, serving the community in so many dimensions, that is really outstanding. I am delighted to say today that of the people I have met in the Sutherland Shire, she would be one of the most outstanding people in the community. She is a person of enormous merit and talent and dedication. I commend her to the House as someone who has served the community outstandingly for a long period of time, and particularly the electorate of Cook.

talk.start.para: —I want to speak this morning about Sydney airport, and it is a shame the member for Cook did not speak about it rather than firming up his preselection in his local Liberal Party branch.

speech.para: Recently, a new radar monitoring system has been trialled at Sydney airport, a precision radar monitoring system. Under this system planes can fly at levels 1,000 feet lower than current levels and descend in spiral patterns, and over the member for Cook's electorate, I might say. While trials have started over Botany Bay there is potential for them to be extended over the land to the north of the airport, and that is what the rumours coming out of Sydney airport are.

Yesterday it was reported in the press that Airservices Australia had been accused of deliberately concealing the noise impact of the system. That noise impact was over the member for Cook's electorate, so it is a pity he did not think about that rather than firming up his support in the local Liberal Party branch. The noise impact is occurring despite the promises of the member for Cook's government that these noise levels would be reduced.

I was not surprised to read that it had happened, given that already there have been complaints. I have received complaints from constituents, and I am sure that other members have received complaints as well. As has been the case before, lack of consultation and withholding of information has been the norm. Now that people have found out what is happening we are being told, `Don't worry, no permanent changes will be made without an EIS and without it being considered by the airport community,' et cetera, even though Airservices Australia is trying to shed responsibility for noise management.

We are also being told that despite the capacity of this system to permit increased usage of runways, it is proposed only as a safety tool. Unfortunately, I am a bit more cynical about that, and the people who live around the airport are too. Unfortunately, the member for Cook does not care.

How is it that noise levels are already increasing with lower flights and increased numbers of flights? Apparently it is because the PRM system allows more flights to land using parallel runways. You can imagine the pressure from the airlines to have a system like this installed permanently, because it will save them millions and millions of dollars, and it could also suit those who are loath to make the decision about the second Sydney airport.

Increasing the potential for the existing airport's capacity to handle aircraft relieves the pressure for the construction of a new airport. Never mind the citizens of Sydney. Eventually their hearing, I suppose, will be so impaired they will not even hear the extra noise.

It makes me angry that this whole airport issue is still unresolved after so many years. Twenty-eight years ago I was elected to local council on a `No extension of Sydney Airport' program, and yet it is still being extended. It is being extended by this rotten, uncaring Liberal government that will not make a decision about Badgerys Creek.

The Badgerys Creek EIS has been put off once again by them because they are afraid of the effect it will have on the New South Wales election. I can only wait with interest to see what happens when the decision comes down in a few weeks time and it is considered by cabinet in June and July. In the meantime we will no doubt continue to see efforts made by the airlines, and by those with vested interests, to put off the hard decision about determining the location of a second Sydney airport. That will increase the noise levels and the capacity of Sydney airport to cause concern to the people who live around the airport.
What concerns me, in particular, are safety issues. A crash at Sydney airport is—
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to talk about a mental health program in the electorate of Boothby called Out of the Blues. This was a mood disorders unit for young people located at Flinders Medical Centre. The problem is that, despite the success of the unit, Out of the Blues has closed its doors.

speech.para: Youth depression, especially youth suicide, is probably the most tragic and distressing problem that confronts the community. Depression is a condition that affects the mind and the body. Severely depressed people are at a greater risk of self-harm and, at worst, suicide. Australia has one of the highest rates of youth suicide. Since 1991 there has been an alarming increase in the rate of young males aged 15 to 34 commiting suicide. It is a sad indictment on all levels of government that it took so long to take action on this issue. The Howard government acted immediately when it was elected in 1996.

Out of the Blues was a program pilot funded by the Commonwealth government for two years under the National Youth Suicide Prevention Strategy. The unit was available to young people aged 18 to 24 and ensured a focus on the age and stage of development in which the first episode of mood disorders is known to occur. Out of the Blues was set up to try and bridge the gap between child and adult mental health services. It provided services to young people suffering from depression and at risk of suicide. Through the unit's marketing process and community acceptance, it attracted a significant number of young people. A significant number of those that attended the service had attempted suicide before attending the unit.

The success of the Out of the Blues unit is highlighted with some statistics. I want to emphasise that statistics do not tell the whole story. Overall, 186 people were referred to the unit, and 104 of those received a psychiatric assessment. Of the 104 that received psychiatric assessment, six were assessed as not having a depressive disorder, 20 declined to return to ongoing treatment, and 78 received ongoing treatment. The average age of young people who attended the unit was 18 and 53 per cent of those treated by the unit were young males. This figure shows the community acceptance of the unit. It was able to receive the trust of a significant proportion of the community that does not normally access these services.

I have no hesitation in saying that, from the information that I have been given, the unit clearly saved lives. It was a one-off grant from the Commonwealth government under the $31 million National Youth Suicide Prevention Strategy. It was intended that the South Australian state government would keep all or part of the program once the pilot was completed. There was a large commitment to build a relationship between the team at Out of the Blues and their clients. The closure of the unit creates a huge breach of trust between people who have the power to do something about the closure of the program and people who are receiving treatment.
The South Australian Minister for Human Services, Dean Brown, has stated:
Out of the Blues . . . has made an outstanding contribution . . . helping young people with their mental health problems and in particular with depression.

The local media in my electorate have reported that the state government is looking at ways to further develop the program and expand it into a statewide service. I encourage the South Australian Minister for Human Services to reopen the unit and help the young people who need it most. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I hope in the future you will be able to visit King Island which is in my electorate.
—I thank you for the invitation.

—Of course, it is well known for its magnificent beef, cheese and dairy products, kelp industry, seafood and tourism. Under the leadership of Mayor Vernon Philbey and his council, it is entering into partnership agreements with the state government in order to create more effective and efficient services for the people of the island.

speech.para: Unfortunately, I would like to draw the attention of this group to the telecommunications problems being experienced on King Island and I have done so over some time. The residents often have poor TV reception to none at all. They have a reduced selection in terms of television coverage and no reception of SBS at all. Unfortunately, they would not meet the criteria of the guidelines for self-help at the moment and the amounts of money required by that community to get SBS are almost prohibitive.

They have no mobile phone coverage on the island at all. This is inequitable. It is an impediment to doing business, both for those on the island and for those coming to the island to do business there and, of course, it affects safety and emergency services. The landline telephone system on the island is proving more and more unreliable and is subject to technical problems from, for example, electronic fencing alone. The dairy on the island had trouble for five weeks with its telephone system. When I went to visit the manager, he told me that he had spent 15 trips travelling to Currie to make phone calls to allow his business to keep operating. There is one technician on the island after several were removed. We were reliably informed, of course, that coverage from Melbourne and Hobart would be sufficient to fix these technical problems, and it is not. There is trouble with faxes, reception and transmitting of faxes, and Internet availability is very intermittent on the island.

We have a Telstra regional telecommunications infrastructure funding. The government is telling us that, unless they can sell the remainder of Telstra, then regional centres like my own on the north-west coast and King Island, in particular, will not receive these upgraded services. That is rot. The $1.6 billion to $1.8 billion dividend a year is available to Telstra and to the government and the people of Australia in order to assist in regional telecommunications infrastructure funding. That is available. All we need is a government that is fair dinkum about helping regional Australia. And that does not mean just the bush. It also means areas a little bit closer to larger population areas. The government's definition and ours about regional and the bush are very different. Telstra can operate now. We do not need to sell any more, because if we do we will have no hope.(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise today to make a plea about the Work for the Dole program: there are simply not enough places in my electorate of Hinkler. There is a high youth unemployment rate in Hinkler, the legacy of 13 years of Labor.

speech.para: Work for the Dole is a great tonic for young people. How do I know this? Because they tell me so. I am advised that 85 per cent of participants say that the program has helped them in their determination to get a job. The figures are quite conclusive. There has been a far better result than anything achieved under the previous labour market programs, which did nothing but churn young unemployed people in a cauldron of hopelessness.

An analysis of 10,000 people in the pilot program found that 32 per cent of the Work for the Dole participants went on to unsubsidised work or further education and training, at a cost of $3,900 per success. This compares very favourably with the Working Nation program under Labor. For example, the LEAP program had a 26 per cent success rate, at a cost of $26,000 per outcome; the Jobskills program had a 30 per cent success rate, at a cost of $36,000 per outcome; and the New Work Opportunities program, Labor's last flagship, had a 21 per cent success rate, for $52,000 per outcome—an absolute disgrace.

In my electorate, a pilot in Bundaberg for the Work for the Dole program has finished, having placed 67 out of 240 participants straight into work. I am expecting similar results from the round 1 program in my other provincial city, Gladstone. In fact, the Bundaberg pilot performed better than the national average of 34 per cent of participants either gaining work or going on to further education and training. Another 35 per cent completed six months with the program, when they were required to do only three months by mutual obligation. If you add the two figures together you get a success rate of 69 per cent. It is clear that Work for the Dole is getting results and that it is significantly better for job seekers themselves and far better for the taxpayer.

However, I have a plea for the Wide Bay-Capricorn statistical regions, where youth unemployment is particularly high. To illustrate my concern: Bundaberg got 240 places in the original pilot program, then only 100 places in round 1 and 86 places in round 2, having tendered for 250. I sincerely hope the numbers pick up again when the results of the upcoming third round tendering are announced. We desperately need those numbers in the Wide Bay-Capricorn statistical regions of Queensland.

talk.start.para: —Order! In accordance with sessional order 275A, the time for members' statements has concluded. The Main Committee will now consider government business.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 10 February, on motion by Mr Slipper:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The opposition supports the Financial Management Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 and I intend to speak only briefly on it. The legislation essentially does two things. It consolidates the four current principal accounts through which government funds are dealt with into a single account. The previous commercial activities fund, loan fund and reserve fund accounts will now become, in a sense, subsets of the consolidated revenue fund and will have, broadly, a single government account.

speech.para: Secondly, it amends the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997 to provide that the requirement for monthly financial statements by the government will be removed for the fiscal year 1999-2000, and for that year only, when there will be a requirement for quarterly statements. After that financial year, the monthly requirement will resume.

The purpose of that latter change is to facilitate the introduction of accrual budgeting which was initiated by the former Labor government. It is something that has occurred or is occurring in all the states; is also occurring in Britain; and either has occurred or will be occurring in many other parts of the world where the traditional basis of budgeting in government which has been using cash transactions as the basis—and capital transactions are rather obscure and difficult to track—is being replaced by a much more logical and sensible approach to public accounting and budgeting.

It will deal with these things on the basis of accruals—that is, when the actual liability or expenditure commitment accrues rather than when the money actually changes hands. Secondly, it will ensure that there is a proper incorporation of the cost of capital within the overall budget framework so that you can actually look at individual programs or agencies and determine both what the cost of capital is with respect to a particular program or agency and how efficiently or inefficiently they are actually using the assets that they have been allocated.

The opposition strongly supports this change and, having kicked the ball off some time ago, we remain committed to the process. There is quite an amount of detail to absorb with this process, and I should add that I am grateful to the government for the briefings and access that they have made available to me and my staff and to opposition members generally to ensure that we are able to get across the detail and ask questions. Thus far I have no complaint about how the government are dealing with the matter.

There is an array of transitional issues which we are seeking to come to terms with. We are in discussions with the government at the moment. I want to flag the core issue we are discussing, that is, the ability for both the opposition and the media to have as much information and understanding about the 1999 budget in the budget lockup on budget night as we were able to get in the 1998, 1997 and 1996 budgets.

The reason this is an issue is that you are essentially changing languages and that makes it very difficult in many areas to make direct comparisons between the forthcoming budget and previous budgets. In some areas it will still be straightforward because you will be dealing with things where the translation from cash accounting to accrual accounting is fairly basic and where it is pretty obvious that, essentially, a direct comparison can be made. But in other areas that may not be the case.

The government has initially suggested that it would provide—and I suspect that it will still do this—an accrual accounting basis assessment of the 1998-99 outcomes and that that will provide some basis for comparison with the 1999 budget. We appreciate that, but we would say that it really is necessary to have the new budget, the 1999 budget, in the old language as well as in the new as a one-off instance so that we—and the media—are able to check comparisons to ensure that when we make statements about what has happened to particular programs compared with what happened to them last year or the previous year we can actually compare apples with apples and that we will know that X program has been increased or reduced by 10 per cent or whatever.

I think it is in everybody's interests that this is facilitated. I understand the government is considering this. There is a range of other associated questions about the level of information that is available and how we go about the budget revelation process which, as I said, the government has been entirely cooperative and helpful with so far. I urge the government to continue on this path, because ultimately this is something which is beneficial for the country and for the budget process irrespective of who happens to be in government, and a painless and controversy free introduction of this process is in everybody's best interests.

talk.start.para: —It is with great pleasure that I rise to speak on the Financial Management Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 . I am also very pleased that the opposition supports this bill, and I thank the member for Melbourne for his comments.
—And for his book, too.

—Absolutely. On 21 February 1996 the then finance minister, now Leader of the Opposition, declared that the budget was foreshadowed to be in surplus. Twelve days later the Department of the Treasury presented figures to the incoming government which showed that the nation was headed for a multibillion dollar deficit.

speech.para: To ensure that such a monstrous deception could never be practised upon the Australian people again, this government enacted the charter of budget honesty requiring that updated budget estimates be released before every federal election. At the same time, we established a Commission of Audit to look into the range of issues relating to the preparation of the national accounts and improving the efficiency of the public sector.

The Commission of Audit, in its report of June 1996, recommended that moving to a full accrual accounting framework was essential in meeting the requirements of the charter of budget honesty. In other words, if the government is to keep faith with the Australian people in a way that the previous government did not, accrual accounting is an essential part of this.

This bill seeks to amend the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997 to change the underlying basis of accounting from a cash to an accrual basis. The Financial Management and Accountability Act was initiated by the previous government and was predicated on a cash based accounting system. This must now be changed to bring it into line with the government's reforms in this area. Businesses—and certainly large businesses—do not manage their affairs on a cash basis. If they did, they would be likely to go broke fairly quickly. Managing their affairs on this basis, they would have no measure of future liabilities, no measure of the extent to which assets were depreciating and no proper measure of expenses which had been prepaid but not yet incurred. Yet this is how governments have been expected to manage until recently. In doing so, they experienced exactly the same sorts of problems. Drains on future funds were not accounted for, the practice of hollow logging, in which assets are starved of resources, could be carried on without being reflected in the financial statements, and assets could be sold with the proceeds going into the current year's revenue, a practice which was rife during the opposition leader's period as Minister for Finance.

These practices will become a thing of the past with the adoption of accrual accounting in the preparation of our financial statements. No longer will governments be rewarded for bad economic management; no longer will it be possible for governments such as the previous Labor government to run down assets and run up liabilities while pretending—there is that word again—that they are managing the economy responsibly. Many times in the past an opposition has attacked the incumbent government for its failure to be transparent in the presentation of its accounts, only to indulge in the same practice when in government.

We are the first party to make our concerns known when in opposition and then make good on our commitments on coming into government. Furthermore this legislation, combined with our charter of budget honesty, commits all future federal governments to the same level of honesty and accountability. Should there ever be another Labor government at some stage in the future—

talk.start.para: —Oh, not for a long time.

—they would have nowhere to hide fudged budget figures. Indeed, it is a pity that Labor did not introduce accrual accounting when it came to office in 1983. It would then not have been able to hide so many of the asset sales that went straight to fund recurrent expenditure.

speech.para: Knowledge is power; by giving people knowledge about the true state of the government's finances this is a very empowering bill. Public sector departments will be much more able to plan expenditure, foresee difficulties and avoid them, and direct resources to where they will be needed in the future. This means that every sector of government will be more efficient and therefore better able to deliver the services that people need.

It is important to note that this does not mean that departments cannot allocate—or hypothecate, to use the correct term—funds for particular programs or activities. It simply requires that this all be done in the context of accrual accounting. Without this bill, funds must be drawn from consolidated revenue and placed in outside funds so that they can be used for their purpose. This bill enables them to be allocated to specific funds within the accrual accounting framework. This bill is important not just for itself but for all of the activities and programs that it facilitates.

I said before that, thanks to this bill, public sector departments will be much better equipped to plan expenditure and direct resources to where they will be needed in the future. This, of course, is the whole point of responsible financial management: it enables us to allocate resources to the social programs which need them most. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —in reply—At the outset, I would like to thank the honourable members for Melbourne and Makin for their contributions and also the opposition for its support of this very important piece of legislation, which is part of our nation's move to accrual budgeting. I am thankful that the opposition supports what the government is proposing to do in this area. I think it really is a good sign being sent to the Australian community that, from both sides of politics, there is an appreciation that there are advantages to our nation and to accountability in making sure that we move to this new budgeting format.

speech.para: As we all know, the Commonwealth's first accrual budget is to be delivered in May this year. The transition to accrual budgeting will require certain amendments to various items of legislation, including the piece of legislation currently before the chamber. Thus, the Financial Management Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 is a vital and important part of this move towards the Commonwealth's first accrual budget.

Summarising the provisions of the bill, it should be noted that the principal amendment it contains is the merger of the loan fund, the reserved money fund, and the commercial activities fund into the consolidated revenue fund. This will enable the obsolete practice of fund accounting to be discontinued and avoid the inefficiency of maintaining dual systems for fund accounting and accrual accounting.

Fund accounting is a relic of the last century. It is simplistic and totally inadequate for the financial management needs of the government and the nation. No longer will there be the requirement of daily transferring moneys back and forth among the funds to keep them in positive balance. Quite frankly, this is simply inefficient and does nothing to improve overall financial management.

For the purpose of managing Commonwealth public debt, this bill will give the Treasurer the same powers of investment as are currently held by the Minister for Finance and Administration under section 39 of the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997. The bill will also widen the range of investments permitted to the Treasurer by adding a further category of investments, that is, securities or other debt interests issued by sovereign governments or international organisations.

Historically, the proposed reforms outlined in the bill were recommended in two reports by a very important committee of this parliament, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit. Those reports were handed down in August 1995 and November 1995. As was mentioned by the honourable member for Melbourne, this was during the time of a Labor government. There is also further widespread support for these reforms as they relate to accrual budgeting. Following the election of the coalition government, the National Commission of Audit was set up, and that commission was referred to by my colleague the honourable member for Makin. It recommended that the government should formally adopt accrual principles as the basis for an integrated budgeting resource management and financial reporting framework.

These reforms will place the government's financial management on a more business-like footing and provide greater transparency of government operations. This government is going about its business of ensuring accountability at every level. The member for Makin also highlighted the sound economic management of the coalition government since it was elected in 1996, and she mentioned the charter of budget honesty and other reforms. We are absolutely and resolutely determined to ensure that there is accountability and sound financial and economic management.

The amendments before the chamber will enable the government to present a more comprehensive view of the budget and the Commonwealth's performance throughout the year by replacing the present cash basis of accounting with the accruals basis of accounting, as is used in the private sector. This means that the full cost of government activities will be transparent, as will all of its assets and liabilities. No longer will governments be able to hide behind off-budget spending or phoney accounting. The government's delivery of services will be enhanced by the reforms contained in this bill. The government will act as a purchaser of agency outputs, specifying the price, the quality and quantity for which it will pay. This will require a business-like approach to service delivery incorporating performance management systems.

The honourable member for Melbourne, in his contribution, seemed to make a plea for the budget this year to be handed down both as a cash budget and also as an accrual budget. There will be a reconciliation this year between the cash result and the accrual result and there will also be included a statement of cash flows. Treasury may also, in the budget documents, make reference to the cash result. But I am advised that it is simply not possible to replicate the detail in the old budget, as the system for the budget this year will be set up in a new format.

The member for Melbourne also referred to the opposition's support of this move to accrual accounting. He asked that members should be made aware of what is happening, of the need for the changes, and of the substance of the changes, so that economic performance this year can be compared with economic performance in earlier years. My colleague the Minister for Finance and Administration has asked me to assist in this educative process and I can guarantee that all members of this place and the Senate, both government and opposition, will have ample opportunity to be briefed on the significance of this very important economic reform, the move to accrual accounting, and they will also receive advice and assistance on how to read the new budget documents. We are not trying to hide anything. We are seeking to bring about a new means of handling the nation's accounts so that the activities of government are more transparent. I thank the honourable member for Melbourne for accepting that the government's motives in this very important reform are positive.

In conclusion, passage of this bill will provide the government with a more complete picture of the performance of Commonwealth agencies and their delivery of services to the Australian community. We are very proud of this piece of legislation and of the move to an accrual budget this year. I commend the bill to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

talk.start.para: —If no member wishes to consider the bill in detail, I will put the report question forthwith. The question is that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.
